translated: Long Discourses with Tens
The Ten Questions
Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā campāyaṁ viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā campāyam viharati gaggarāya pokkharaṇiyā tīre mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim pañcamattehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred monks.

original: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho āyasmā sāriputtaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the venerable Sāriputta addressed the monks:
“Venerable friends!”

original: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa
translated: “Venerable friend!” those monks replied.
Sāriputta said this:
“I will proclaim the tenfold
Dhamma that leads to Nibbāna,
To the end of suffering,
The liberation from all bondage.

original: 1. Eko dhammo🔽Eko, āvuso, dhammo bahukāro, eko dhammo bhāvetabbo, eko dhammo pariññeyyo, eko dhammo
analyzed: ekaḥ dhammaḥ  ekaḥ āvuso dhammaḥ bahu kāraḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ bhāvetabbaḥ ekaḥ dhammo pariññeyyaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ
translated: One thing

original: pahātabbo, eko dhammo hānabhāgiyo, eko dhammo visesabhāgiyo, eko dhammo duppaṭivijjho,
analyzed: pahātabbaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ hāna bhāgiyaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ visesa bhāgiyaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ duppaṭivijjhaḥ
translated: There is one thing, friends, that is very helpful. There is one thing that should be developed. There is one thing that should be fully understood. There is one thing that should be given up. There is one thing that leads to decline. There is one thing that leads to distinction. There is one thing that is hard to penetrate.

original: eko dhammo uppādetabbo, eko dhammo abhiññeyyo, eko dhammo sacchikātabbo.
analyzed: ekaḥ dhammaḥ uppādetabbaḥ ekaḥ dhammaḥ abhiññeyyaḥ ekaḥ dhammo sacchikātabbaḥ
translated: There is one thing that should be made to arise. There is one thing that should be directly known. There is one thing that should be realized.
Which one thing is very helpful?
Heedfulness in wholesome qualities.
This one thing is very helpful.
Which one thing should be developed?
Mindfulness related to the body accompanied by bliss.
This one thing should be developed.
Which one thing should be fully understood?
Contact that is accompanied by taints, which leads to further becoming.
This one thing should be fully understood.
Which one thing should be given up?
Conceit “I am.”
This one thing should be given up.
Which one thing is on the side of decline?
Inappropriate attention.
This one thing is on the side of decline.
Which one thing is on the side of distinction?
Appropriate attention.
This one thing is on the side of distinction.
Which one thing is hard to penetrate?
The uninterrupted concentration of the mind.
This one thing is hard to penetrate.
Which one thing should be brought into being?
Unwavering knowledge.
This one thing should be brought into being.
Which one thing should be directly known?
All beings subsist on nutriment.
This is one thing to be directly known.
• “Which one thing to be realized?
The unshakeable liberation of mind.
This is one thing to be realized.

original: Iti ime dasa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
analyzed: iti ime dasa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā
translated: “These are the ten things that are real, true, actual, authentic, not inauthentic, not otherwise, that have been realized by the Tathāgata.
. Two Dhammas

original: Dve dhammā bahukārā, dve dhammā bhāvetabbā, dve dhammā pariññeyyā, dve dhammā pahātabbā,
analyzed: dve dhammā bahukārā dve dhammā bhāvetabbā dve dhammā pariññeyyā dve dhammā pahātabbā
translated: “Two dhammas, friends, are very helpful. Two dhammas should be developed. Two dhammas should be comprehended. Two dhammas should be abandoned.

original: dve dhammā hānabhāgiyā, dve dhammā visesabhāgiyā, dve dhammā duppaṭivijjhā, dve dhammā
analyzed: dve dhammā hāna bhāgiyāḥ dve dhammāḥ visesa bhāgiyāḥ dve dhammāḥ duppaṭivijjhāḥ dve dhammāḥ
translated: Two dhammas are on the side of decline. Two dhammas are on the side of distinction. Two dhammas are hard to penetrate.

original: uppādetabbā, dve dhammā abhiññeyyā, dve dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: uppādetabbā dve dhammā abhiññeyyā dve dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: Two dhammas are to be made to arise. Two dhammas are to be directly known. Two dhammas are to be realized.
• “Which two dhammas are very helpful?
Mindfulness & alertness.
These are two dhammas that are very helpful.
• “Which two dhammas should be developed?
Serenity & discernment.
These are two dhammas that should be developed.
• “Which two dhammas should be comprehended?
Name & form.
These are two dhammas that should be comprehended.
What are the two dhammas that should be developed?
Ignorance and craving for becoming.
These are the two dhammas that should be developed.
What are the two dhammas that are on the side of decline?

analyzed: dovacassatā ca pāpa mitta tā ca
translated: Being difficult to speak to and having bad friends.
These are the two dhammas that are on the side of decline.
What are the two dhammas that are on the side of distinction?

analyzed: sovacassatā ca kalyāṇa mitta tā ca
translated: Being easy to speak to and having good friends.
These are the two dhammas that are on the side of distinction.
What are the two dhammas that are hard to penetrate?

original: Yo ca hetu yo ca paccayo sattānaṁ saṅkilesāya, yo ca hetu yo ca paccayo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā.
analyzed: yaḥ ca hetu yaḥ ca paccayaḥ sattānam saṅkilesāya yaḥ ca hetu yaḥ ca paccayaḥ sattānam visuddhiyā
translated: The cause and condition for the defilement of beings, and the cause and condition for the purification of beings.
These are the two dhammas that are hard to penetrate.
What are the two dhammas that should be made to arise?
There are two kinds of knowledge:
knowledge of destruction and knowledge of non-arising.
These are the two dhammas that should be made to arise.
What are the two dhammas that should be directly known?
There are two properties:

original: saṅkhatā ca dhātu asaṅkhatā ca dhātu.
analyzed: saṅkhatā ca dhātu asaṅkhatā ca dhātu
translated: the conditioned property and the unconditioned property.
These are the two dhammas that should be directly known.
What are the two dhammas that should be realized?
Clear knowledge and freedom.
These are the two dhammas that should be realized.

original: Iti ime vīsati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
analyzed: iti ime vīsati dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā
translated: These twenty dhammas—true, genuine, real, not unreal, not otherwise—have been rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata.
Three dhammas

original: Tayo dhammā bahukārā, tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe… tayo dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: tayaḥ dhammā bahukārā tayaḥ dhammā bhāvetabbā pe tayaḥ dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: There are three dhammas that are very helpful, three dhammas that should be developed, … three dhammas that should be comprehended, … three dhammas that should be given up, … three dhammas that are on the side of decline, … three dhammas that are on the side of distinction, … three dhammas that are hard to penetrate, … three dhammas that should be made to arise, … three dhammas that should be directly known, … three dhammas that should be realized.
• “Which three dhammas are very helpful?
Association with good people, listening to the true Teaching, practicing the Teaching in accordance with the Teaching.
These three dhammas are very helpful.
• “Which three dhammas should be developed?
There are three concentrations:

original: savitakko savicāro samādhi, avitakko vicāramatto samādhi, avitakko avicāro samādhi.
analyzed: sa vitakkaḥ sa vicāraḥ samādhi a vitakkaḥ vicāra mattaḥ samādhi a vitakkaḥ a vicāraḥ samādhi
translated: concentration with thinking & exploring, concentration without thinking but with just exploring, concentration without either thinking or exploring.
These three dhammas should be developed.
• “Which three dhammas should be comprehended?
There are three feelings:

original: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
analyzed: sukhā vedanā dukkhā vedanā adukkhamasukhā vedanā
translated: pleasant, painful, and neither-pleasant-nor-painful.
These three dhammas should be comprehended.
• “Which three dhammas should be given up?
There are three cravings:

analyzed: kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā
translated: craving for sensuality, craving for becoming, craving for non-becoming.
These are the three ideas that should be abandoned.
• “Which three ideas are on the side of decline?
Three roots of what is unskillful:

original: lobho akusalamūlaṁ, doso akusalamūlaṁ, moho akusalamūlaṁ.
analyzed: lobhaḥ akusala mūla dosaḥ akusala mūla mohaḥ akusala mūla
translated: greed as a root of what is unskillful, aversion as a root of what is unskillful, delusion as a root of what is unskillful.
These are the three ideas that are on the side of decline.
• “Which three ideas are on the side of distinction?
Three roots of what is skillful:

original: alobho kusalamūlaṁ, adoso kusalamūlaṁ, amoho kusalamūlaṁ.
analyzed: a lobhaḥ kusala mūla a dosaḥ kusala mūla a mohaḥ kusala mūla
translated: non-greed as a root of what is skillful, non-aversion as a root of what is skillful, non-delusion as a root of what is skillful.
These are the three ideas that are on the side of distinction.
• “Which three ideas are hard to penetrate?
Three properties of escape:

original: kāmānametaṁ nissaraṇaṁ yadidaṁ nekkhammaṁ, rūpānametaṁ nissaraṇaṁ yadidaṁ arūpaṁ, yaṁ kho pana kiñci bhūtaṁ saṅkhataṁ paṭiccasamuppannaṁ, nirodho tassa nissaraṇaṁ.
analyzed: kāmānam etam nissaraṇam yat idam nekkhamma rūpānam etam nissaraṇam yat idam arūpa yam kho pana kiñci bhūtam saṅkhatam paṭiccasamuppanna nirodho tassa nissaraṇa
translated: The escape from sensuality is this: renunciation. The escape from form is this: formlessness. The escape from what is subject to arising, to passing away, to alteration while standing, is this: cessation.
These are the three ideas that are hard to penetrate.
• “Which three ideas should be made to arise?
Three kinds of knowledge:

original: atītaṁse ñāṇaṁ, anāgataṁse ñāṇaṁ, paccuppannaṁse ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: anāgata se ñāṇa paccuppanna se ñāṇa
translated: knowledge of the past, knowledge of the future, and knowledge of the present.
These are the three ideas that should be made to arise.
• “Which three dhammas should be directly known?
Three properties:
the property of sensuality, the property of form, the property of the formless.
These three dhammas should be directly known.
• “Which three dhammas should be realized?
Three knowledges:

original: pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṁ vijjā, sattānaṁ cutūpapāte ñāṇaṁ vijjā, āsavānaṁ khaye ñāṇaṁ vijjā.
analyzed: pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇam vijjā sattānam cutūpapāte ñāṇam vijjā āsavānam khaye ñāṇam vijjā
translated: the knowledge of recollecting one’s past lives, the knowledge of the passing away & arising of beings, the knowledge of the ending of the effluents.
These three dhammas should be realized.

original: Iti ime tiṁsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.🔽4. Cattāro dhammā
analyzed: iti ime tisa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā  cattāro dhammā
translated: “These thirty dhammas—true, genuine, real, not unreal, not otherwise—have been rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata.

original: Cattāro dhammā bahukārā, cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā …pe… cattāro dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: cattāro dhammā bahukārā cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā pe cattāro dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: • “Four dhammas, friends, are very helpful. Four dhammas should be developed. Four dhammas should be comprehended. Four dhammas should be abandoned. Four dhammas are on the side of decline. Four dhammas are on the side of distinction. Four dhammas are hard to penetrate. Four dhammas should be made to arise. Four dhammas should be directly known. Four dhammas should be realized.
• “Which four dhammas are very helpful?
Four wheels:

original: patirūpadesavāso, sappurisūpanissayo, attasammāpaṇidhi, pubbe ca katapuññatā.
analyzed: patir upadesa vāsaḥ sappurisa upanissayaḥ atta sammāpaṇidhi pubbe ca kata puñña tā
translated: living in a suitable region, associating with people of integrity, having right livelihood, having done merit in the past.
These four dhammas are very helpful.
• “Which four dhammas should be developed?
Four establishings of mindfulness:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: There is the case where a monk remains focused on the body in & of itself—ardent, alert, & mindful—subduing greed & distress with reference to the world.
He remains focused on feelings in & of themselves…
He remains focused on the mind in & of itself…

original: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
analyzed: dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He remains focused on mental qualities in & of themselves—ardent, alert, & mindful—subduing greed & distress with reference to the world.
These are the four dhammas that should be developed.
• “Which four dhammas should be comprehended?
There are four nutriments:

original: kabaḷīkāro āhāro oḷāriko vā sukhumo vā, phasso dutiyo, manosañcetanā tatiyā, viññāṇaṁ catutthaṁ.
analyzed: kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ oḷārikaḥ vā sukhumaḥ vā phassaḥ dutiyaḥ manaḥ sañcetanā tatiyā viññāṇam catuttha
translated: physical food, gross or refined; contact as the second, consciousness the third, and mental intention the fourth.
These are the four dhammas that should be comprehended.
• “Which four dhammas should be abandoned?
There are four floods:

analyzed: kāma oghaḥ bhava oghaḥ diṭṭha oghaḥ avijja oghaḥ
translated: the flood of sensuality, the flood of becoming, the flood of views, the flood of ignorance.
These are the four dhammas that should be abandoned.
• “Which four dhammas are on the side of decline?
There are four yokes:

analyzed: kāma yogaḥ bhava yogaḥ diṭṭhi yogaḥ avijjā yogaḥ
translated: the yoke of sensuality, the yoke of becoming, the yoke of views, the yoke of ignorance.
These are the four dhammas that are on the side of decline.
• “Which four dhammas are on the side of distinction?
There are four kinds of disconnections:

analyzed: kāma yoga visayogaḥ bhava yoga visayogaḥ diṭṭhi yoga visayogaḥ avijjā yoga visayogaḥ
translated: disconnection from the fetter of sensuality, disconnection from the fetter of becoming, disconnection from the fetter of views, disconnection from the fetter of ignorance.
These four dhammas are on the side of distinction.
• “Which four dhammas are hard to penetrate?
There are four concentrations:

original: hānabhāgiyo samādhi, ṭhitibhāgiyo samādhi, visesabhāgiyo samādhi, nibbedhabhāgiyo samādhi.
analyzed: hāna bhāgiyo samādhi ṭhiti bhāgiyo samādhi visesa bhāgiyo samādhi nibbedha bhāgiyo samādhi
translated: the concentration that is conducive to falling away, the concentration that is conducive to stationariness, the concentration that is conducive to penetration, the concentration that is conducive to direct knowledge.
These four dhammas are hard to penetrate.
• “Which four dhammas should be made to arise?
There are four kinds of knowledge:

original: dhamme ñāṇaṁ, anvaye ñāṇaṁ, pariye ñāṇaṁ, sammutiyā ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: dhamme ñāṇa anvaye ñāṇa pariye ñāṇa sammutiyā ñāṇa
translated: knowledge of the Dhamma, knowledge of language, knowledge of others’ minds, knowledge of conventions.
These four dhammas should be made to arise.
• “Which four dhammas should be directly known?
There are four noble truths:

original: dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhanirodhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṁ.🔽Ime cattāro dhammā abhiññeyyā.
analyzed: dukkham ariya sat ca dukkha samudayam ariya sat ca dukkha nirodham ariya sat ca dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya sat ca  ime cattāraḥ dhammā abhiññeyyā
translated: the noble truth of stress, the noble truth of the origination of stress, the noble truth of the cessation of stress, the noble truth of the path of practice leading to the cessation of stress.🔽These four dhammas should be directly known.
• “Which four dhammas should be realized?
• There are four fruits of asceticism:

analyzed: sa utāpatti phala sakadāgāmi phala anāgāmi phala arahatta phala
translated: the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, and the fruit of arahantship.
These are the four dhammas that should be realized.

original: Iti ime cattārīsadhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.🔽5. Pañca dhammā
analyzed: iti ime cattārīsadhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā  pañca dhammā
translated: These forty dhammas—real, true, actual, realizable, to be directly known—were rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata.

original: Pañca dhammā bahukārā …pe… pañca dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: pañca dhammā bahu kārā pe pañca dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: • There are five dhammas that are very helpful, five dhammas that are very harmful, five dhammas that are to be developed, five dhammas that are to be comprehended, five dhammas that are to be abandoned, five dhammas that are to be given up, five dhammas that are on the side of decline, five dhammas that are on the side of distinction, five dhammas that are hard to penetrate, and five dhammas that should be made to arise.
• Which five dhammas are very helpful?
There are these five factors of striving:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṁ:
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu saddhaḥ hoti saddahati tathāgatassa bodhi
translated: There is the case where a monk has conviction, is convinced of the Tathāgata’s awakening:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘Indeed, the Blessed One is worthy & rightly self-awakened, consummate in clear-knowing & conduct, well-gone, an expert with regard to the cosmos, unexcelled trainer of people fit to be tamed, teacher of devas & human beings, awakened, blessed.’

original: Appābādho hoti appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya majjhimāya padhānakkhamāya.
analyzed: appa ābādhaḥ hoti appa ātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgataḥ na ati sītāya na accuṇhāya majjhimāya padhāna kkhamāya
translated: He is free from illness & discomfort, endowed with good digestion—not too cold, not too hot, of moderate strength—fit for exertion.

original: Asaṭho hoti amāyāvī yathābhūtamattānaṁ āvīkattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
analyzed: a saṭhaḥ hoti a māyāvī yathābhūtam attānam āvīkattā satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu
translated: He is not deceitful or hypocritical, and does not show himself to others as possessing special qualities that he does not have.

original: Āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānāya, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
analyzed: āraddha vīriyaḥ viharati akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya kusalānam dhammānam upasampadāya thāmavā daḷha parakkamaḥ a nikkhitta dhuraḥ kusalesu dhammesu
translated: He is energetic in giving up unwholesome thoughts and in developing wholesome thoughts, steadfast, firm in his effort, not giving up his task.

original: Paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
analyzed: paññavā hoti udaya ttha gāminiyā paññāya samannāgataḥ ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkha kkhaya gāminiyā
translated: He is wise, possessing wisdom directed to arising and passing away, which is noble and penetrative, leading to the complete destruction of suffering.
These five dhammas are very helpful.
• “Which five dhammas should be developed?
Right concentration with five factors:

analyzed: pīti pharaṇa tā sukha pharaṇa tā cetaḥ pharaṇa tā āloka pharaṇa tā paccavekkhaṇa nimitta
translated: the pervasiveness of rapture, the pervasiveness of bliss, the pervasiveness of mind, the pervasiveness of light, and the object of reflection.
These five dhammas should be developed.
• “Which five dhammas should be comprehended?
Five clinging-aggregates:

analyzed: rūpa upādāna khandhaḥ vedanā upādāna khandhaḥ saññu pādāna khandhaḥ saṅkhāru pādāna khandhaḥ viññāṇu pādāna khandhaḥ
translated: the form clinging-aggregate, the feeling clinging-aggregate, the perception clinging-aggregate, the fabrication clinging-aggregate, the consciousness clinging-aggregate.
These five dhammas should be fully understood.
• “Which five dhammas should be abandoned?
Five hindrances:

analyzed: kāmacchanda nīvaraṇa byāpāda nīvaraṇa thinamiddha nīvaraṇa uddhacca kukkucca nīvaraṇa vicikicchā nīvaraṇa
translated: the hindrance of sensual desire, the hindrance of ill will, the hindrance of sloth & drowsiness, the hindrance of restlessness & anxiety, the hindrance of doubt.
These five dhammas should be abandoned.
• “Which five dhammas are on the side of decline?

original: Pañca cetokhilā—🔽idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati.
analyzed: pañca  idha āvuso bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati na adhimuccati na sampasīdati
translated: Five mental blockages:🔽There is the case, friends, where a monk is doubtful, uncertain, indecisive, & lacking clarity regarding the Teacher.

original: Yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati nādhimuccati na sampasīdati, tassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.🔽Yassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ āvuso bhikkhu satthari kaṅkhati vicikicchati na adhimuccati na sampasīdati tassa cittam na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya  yassa cittam na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya
translated: When a monk is doubtful, uncertain, indecisive, & lacking clarity regarding the Teacher, his mind does not launch out upon them, does not settle down upon them, does not become serene, steadfast, & resolute upon them.
When the mind does not launch out upon them, settle down upon them, become serene, steadfast, & resolute upon them, that is the first mental blockage.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu dhamme kaṅkhati vicikicchati pe
translated: “And further, the monk is doubtful, uncertain, indecisive, & lacking clarity regarding the Dhamma.
He is doubtful, uncertain, indecisive, & lacking clarity regarding the Saṅgha.

original: sikkhāya kaṅkhati vicikicchati …pe…🔽sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, yo so, āvuso, bhikkhu
analyzed: sikkhāya kaṅkhati vicikicchati pe  sabrahmacārīsu kupitaḥ hoti anatta manaḥ āhata citto khila jātaḥ yaḥ saḥ āvuso bhikkhu
translated: he is doubtful about the training, uncertain, undecided, and unconfident …🔽he is angry and displeased with his companions in the holy life, resentful and callous towards them.🔽A monk who is angry and displeased with his companions in the holy life, resentful and callous towards them,🔽his mind does not incline to ardor, devotion, perseverance, and striving.

original: sabrahmacārīsu kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto, tassa cittaṁ na namati🔽ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.🔽Yassa cittaṁ na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya.
analyzed: sabrahmacārīsu kupitaḥ hoti anatta manaḥ āhata citto khila jāto tassa cittam na namati  ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya  yassa cittam na namati ātappāya anuyogāya sātaccāya padhānāya
translated: When the mind does not incline to ardor, devotion, perseverance, and striving,
this is the fifth obstruction.
These five qualities lead to decline.
What are the five qualities that lead to distinction?
The five faculties:
the faculty of faith, the faculty of energy, the faculty of mindfulness, the faculty of concentration, and the faculty of wisdom.
These five qualities lead to distinction.
What are the five things that are difficult to penetrate?
The five properties that lead to deliverance:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhuno kāme manasikaroto kāmesu cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhuno kāme manasikarotaḥ kāmesu cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati
translated: There is the case, friends, where a monk, as he reflects, does not enjoy being attached to sensual pleasures. His mind does not incline to sensual pleasures, does not rejoice in sensual pleasures, does not launch out into sensual pleasures, does not settle down in sensual pleasures, does not get stuck in sensual pleasures.

original: Nekkhammaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto nekkhamme cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
analyzed: nekkhammam kho panassa manasikarotaḥ nekkhamme cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati
translated: When he brings non-greed to mind, his mind enters into it, finds satisfaction in it, places confidence in it, and resolves upon it.

original: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ kāmehi.
analyzed: tassa tam cittam sugatam su bhāvitam su vuṭṭhitam su vimuttam visa yuttam kāmehi
translated: His mind is well-restrained, well-directed, well-composed, and well-released in that he is released from greed.

original: Ye ca kāmapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
analyzed: ye ca kāma paccayāḥ uppajjanti āsavāḥ vighātā pariḷāhāḥ muttaḥ saḥ tehi na saḥ tam vedanam vedeti
translated: And whatever fetters, vexations, or fevers there are that arise in dependence on greed, he is free from them. He does not experience that feeling.

original: Idamakkhātaṁ kāmānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno byāpādaṁ manasikaroto byāpāde cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.🔽Abyāpādaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto abyāpāde cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
analyzed: idam akkhātam kāmānam nissaraṇa  puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhunaḥ byāpādam manasikarotaḥ byāpāde cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati  a byāpādam kho panassa manasikarotaḥ a byāpāde cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati
translated: This is expounded as the escape from greed.🔽“Again, a bhikkhu brings ill will to mind…🔽When he brings non-ill will to mind, his mind enters into it, finds satisfaction in it, places confidence in it, and resolves upon it.

original: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ byāpādena.
analyzed: tassa tam cittam sugatam su bhāvitam su vuṭṭhitam su vimuttam visa yuttam byāpādena
translated: His mind is well-restrained, well-directed, well-composed, and well-released in that he is released from ill will.

original: Ye ca byāpādapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
analyzed: ye ca byāpāda paccayāḥ uppajjanti āsavāḥ vighātā pariḷāhāḥ muttaḥ saḥ tehi na saḥ tam vedanam vedeti
translated: And the taints, vexation, or fever that might arise in dependence on ill will do not arise when one’s mind is free from ill will. One does not experience those feelings.
This is expounded as the escape from ill will.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno vihesaṁ manasikaroto vihesāya cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.🔽Avihesaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto avihesāya cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
analyzed: punar caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhuno vihesam manasikarotaḥ vihesāya cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati  a vihesam kho panassa manasikarotaḥ a vihesāya cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu does not direct his mind to the thought of harming. When he does not direct his mind to the thought of harming, his mind does not leap up at the thought of harming, does not find satisfaction in the thought of harming, does not settle down in the thought of harming, does not rejoice in the thought of harming.🔽But when he directs his mind to the thought of non-harming, his mind leaps up at the thought of non-harming, finds satisfaction in the thought of non-harming, settles down in the thought of non-harming, and delights in the thought of non-harming.

original: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ vihesāya.
analyzed: tassa tam cittam sugatam su bhāvitam su vuṭṭhitam su vimuttam visa yuttam vihesāya
translated: His mind being thus straight, well purified, spotless, free from imperfection, malleable, wieldy, and radiant, he directs it to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints. He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; … ‘This is the origin of suffering’; … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering’; … ‘These are the taints’; … ‘This is the origin of the taints’; … ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Ye ca vihesāpaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
analyzed: ye ca vihesā paccayāḥ uppajjanti āsavāḥ vighātā pariḷāhāḥ muttaḥ saḥ tehi na saḥ tam vedanam vedeti
translated: And the taints, vexation, or fever that might arise in dependence on the thought of harming do not arise when one’s mind is free from the thought of harming. One does not experience those feelings.
This is expounded as the escape from the thought of harming.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno rūpe manasikaroto rūpesu cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhuno rūpe manasikarotaḥ rūpesu cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu does not direct his mind to form. When he does not direct his mind to form, his mind does not leap up at the thought of form, does not find satisfaction in the thought of form, does not settle down in the thought of form, does not rejoice in the thought of form.

original: Arūpaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto arūpe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.🔽Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ rūpehi.
analyzed: arūpam kho panassa manasikarotaḥ arūpe cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati  tassa tam cittam sugatam su bhāvitam su vuṭṭhitam su vimuttam visa yuttam rūpehi
translated: His mind being thus rightly concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of defilement, malleable, wieldy, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽He understands as it really is: “This is suffering”; … “This is the origin of suffering”; … “This is the cessation of suffering”; … “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering”; … “These are the taints”; … “This is the origin of the taints”; … “This is the cessation of the taints”; … “This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.”

original: Ye ca rūpapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.🔽Idamakkhātaṁ rūpānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ.
analyzed: ye ca rūpa paccayāḥ uppajjanti āsavāḥ vighātā pariḷāhāḥ muttaḥ saḥ tehi na saḥ tam vedanam vedeti  rūpānam nissaraṇa
translated: This is called the escape from form.🔽“Again, a bhikkhu does not bring his mind into conformity with the earth…

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno sakkāyaṁ manasikaroto sakkāye cittaṁ na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati.🔽Sakkāyanirodhaṁ kho panassa manasikaroto sakkāyanirodhe cittaṁ pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati.
analyzed: puna capare āvuso bhikkhuno sakkāyam manasikaroto sakkāye cittam na pakkhandati na pasīdati na santiṭṭhati na vimuccati  sakkāya nirodham kho panassa manasikaroto sakkāya nirodhe cittam pakkhandati pasīdati santiṭṭhati vimuccati
translated: He brings his mind into conformity with the cessation of the taints.🔽His mind being thus rightly concentrated, purified, cleansed, unblemished, rid of defilement, malleable, wieldy, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: Tassa taṁ cittaṁ sugataṁ subhāvitaṁ suvuṭṭhitaṁ suvimuttaṁ visaṁyuttaṁ sakkāyena.
analyzed: tassa tam cittam sugatam su bhāvitam su vuṭṭhitam su vimuttam visa yuttam sakkāyena
translated: He understands as it really is: “This is suffering”; … “This is the origin of suffering”; … “This is the cessation of suffering”; … “This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering”; … “These are the taints”; … “This is the origin of the taints”; … “This is the cessation of the taints”; … “This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.”

original: Ye ca sakkāyapaccayā uppajjanti āsavā vighātā pariḷāhā, mutto so tehi. Na so taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti.
analyzed: ye ca sakkāya paccayāḥ uppajjanti āsavāḥ vighātā pariḷāhāḥ muttaḥ saḥ tehi na saḥ tam vedanam vedeti
translated: And whatever corruptions, vexations, or fevers there might be that arise in dependence on personal existence, he is free from them. He does not experience that feeling.
This is the escape from personal existence.
These five dhammas are hard to penetrate.
• “Which five dhammas should be made to arise?

original: Pañca ñāṇiko sammāsamādhi:🔽‘ayaṁ samādhi paccuppannasukho ceva āyatiñca sukhavipāko’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.🔽‘Ayaṁ samādhi ariyo nirāmiso’ti paccattaññeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.🔽‘Ayaṁ samādhi akāpurisasevito’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.🔽‘Ayaṁ samādhi santo paṇīto paṭippassaddhaladdho ekodibhāvādhigato, na sasaṅkhāraniggayhavāritagato’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
analyzed: pañca ñāṇiko sammāsamādhi  ayam samādhi paccuppanna sukho ca iva āyatim ca sukha vipāko ti paccattayā iva ñāṇam uppajjati  ayam samādhi ariyaḥ nirāmisaḥ ti paccattaññā iva ñāṇam uppajjati  ayam samādhi a kāpurisa sevito ti paccattayā iva ñāṇam uppajjati  ayam samādhi santaḥ paṇītaḥ paṭippassaddha laddhaḥ ekodi bhāva adhigataḥ na sa saṅkhāra niggayha vārita gataḥ ti paccattayā iva ñāṇam uppajjati
translated: Right concentration with five aspects of knowledge:

original: ‘So kho panāhaṁ imaṁ samādhiṁ satova samāpajjāmi sato vuṭṭhahāmī’ti paccattaṁyeva ñāṇaṁ uppajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kho pana aham imam samādhim sataḥ iva samāpajjāmi sataḥ vuṭṭhahāmi iti paccattayā iva ñāṇam uppajjati
translated: ‘This concentration is pleasant now and ripens in the future to pleasure.’ Knowledge arises in him: ‘This concentration is noble and free from sensuality.’ Knowledge arises in him: ‘This concentration is not to be pursued by one of impure habits.’ Knowledge arises in him: ‘This concentration is peaceful, sublime, and surpasses the human.’ Knowledge arises in him: ‘This concentration is to be pursued by one of pure habits.’ Knowledge arises in him: ‘I enter into this concentration mindfully, and mindfully I emerge from it.’
These five dhammas should be made to arise.
• “Which five dhammas should be directly known?

original: Pañca vimuttāyatanāni—🔽idhāvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṁ deseti aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī.
analyzed: pañca vimutta āyatanāni  idha āvuso bhikkhuno satthā dhammam deseti aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhāniyaḥ sabrahmacārī
translated: Five openings to release:🔽“There is the case, friends, where a monk’s teacher teaches him the Dhamma: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’🔽Or another venerable one teaches him the Dhamma: ‘This is for your welfare. This is for your happiness.’

original: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
analyzed: yathā yathā āvuso bhikkhuno satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhāniyaḥ sabrahmacārī tathā tathā so tasmin dhamme attha paṭisavedī ca hoti dhamma paṭisavedī ca
translated: As he is being taught the Dhamma, he experiences happiness & joy in connection with that Dhamma.

original: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa attha paṭisavedinaḥ dhamma paṭisavedinaḥ pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: In one who is happy & joyful, rapture arises. In one who is rapturous, the body grows calm. When the body is calm, one feels pleasure. Feeling pleasure, the mind becomes concentrated.
This is the first opening to release.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo sabrahmacārī, api ca kho yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhunaḥ na ha iva kho satthā dhammam deseti aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhāniyaḥ sabrahmacārī api ca kho yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena paresam deseti
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu does not receive the Dhamma in detail…🔽but he teaches the Dhamma to others in detail, as he has heard it, as he has learned it.

original: yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
analyzed: yathā yathā āvuso bhikkhu yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena paresam deseti tathā tathā so tasmin dhamme attha paṭisavedī ca hoti dhamma paṭisavedī ca
translated: As he does so, he gains knowledge of its meaning and its text.

original: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa attha paṭisavedinaḥ dhamma paṭisavedinaḥ pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When he knows the meaning and the text, joy arises in him. When he is joyful, rapture arises. When the mind is uplifted by rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, he feels bliss. And when he is blissful, his mind becomes concentrated.
This is the second opening to release.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo
analyzed: puna capare āvuso bhikkhuno na ha iva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhāniyaḥ
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu does not receive the Dhamma in detail…

original: sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti.🔽Api ca kho yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti.
analyzed: sabrahmacārī na api yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena paresam deseti  api ca kho yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena sajjhāyam karoti
translated: nor teaches the Dhamma to others in detail as he has heard it and learned it.🔽But he recites the Dhamma in detail as he has heard it and learned it.

original: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhu yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
analyzed: yathā yathā āvuso bhikkhu yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena sajjhāyam karoti tathā tathā so tasmin dhamme attha paṭisavedī ca hoti dhamma paṭisavedī ca
translated: As he recites the Dhamma in detail as he has heard it and learned it, he gains both the text and the meaning.

original: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa attha paṭisavedinaḥ dhamma paṭisavedinaḥ pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When he gains both the text and the meaning, joy arises in him. When he is joyful, rapture arises. When the mind is uplifted by rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, he feels bliss. And when he is blissful, his mind becomes concentrated.

original: Idaṁ tatiyaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo
analyzed: idam tatiyam vimutta āyatana  puna capare āvuso bhikkhuno na ha iva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhāniyaḥ
translated: This is the third opening to release.🔽“Again, the Dhamma is not taught by the Teacher for the sake of disciples, nor is it taught by another who is learned, an expert on the Dhamma, but

original: sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti,
analyzed: sabrahmacārī na api yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena paresam deseti
translated: the bhikkhu teaches the Dhamma to others in detail as he has heard it and learned it.

original: nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti.

translated: nor does he recite the Dhamma in detail to others as he has heard it and learned it.🔽But he thinks thoughts about the Dhamma in the way he has heard it and learned it,
