analyzed: api ca kho yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasā anupekkhati  yathā yathā āvuso bhikkhu yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam cetasā anuvitakketi
translated: and he examines and investigates that Dhamma with his mind.🔽As he does so, he becomes aware of the meaning and the Dhamma of that Dhamma.

original: anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī ca hoti🔽dhammapaṭisaṁvedī ca.
analyzed: anuvicāreti manasā anupekkhati tathā tathā so tasmin dhamme attha paṭisavedī ca hoti  dhamma paṭisavedī ca
translated: Being aware of the meaning and the Dhamma of that Dhamma, he experiences joy connected with the Dhamma.

original: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammapaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa attha paṭisavedinaḥ dhamma paṭisavedinaḥ pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When he is joyful, rapture arises. When the mind is uplifted by rapture, the body becomes tranquil. One tranquil in body experiences happiness.
This is the fourth opening to release.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno na heva kho satthā dhammaṁ deseti, aññataro vā garuṭṭhāniyo
analyzed: puna capare āvuso bhikkhuno na ha iva kho satthā dhammaṃ deseti aññataraḥ vā garuṭṭhāniyaḥ
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu is not one who teaches the Dhamma to others in detail as he has heard it and learned it,

original: sabrahmacārī, nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena paresaṁ deseti,🔽nāpi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ vitthārena sajjhāyaṁ karoti, nāpi yathāsutaṁ
analyzed: sabrahmacārī na api yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena paresam deseti  na api yathā sutam yathā pariyattam dhammam vitthārena sajjhāyam karoti na api yathā suta
translated: nor teaches the Dhamma to others in detail as he has heard it and learned it,

original: yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasānupekkhati;
analyzed: yathā pariyattam dhammam cetasā anuvitakketi anuvicāreti manasā anupekkhati
translated: nor recites the Dhamma in detail as he has heard it and learned it, nor does he think thoughts about the Dhamma in accordance with what he has heard and learned,🔽but he has taken up a meditation subject well, has given it proper attention,

original: api ca khvassa aññataraṁ samādhinimittaṁ suggahitaṁ hoti sumanasikataṁ sūpadhāritaṁ suppaṭividdhaṁ paññāya.
analyzed: api ca khvassa aññataram samādhi nimittam suggahitam hoti su manasikatam su upadhāritam suppaṭividdham paññāya
translated: has properly penetrated it with wisdom.

original: Yathā yathā, āvuso, bhikkhuno aññataraṁ samādhinimittaṁ suggahitaṁ hoti sumanasikataṁ🔽sūpadhāritaṁ suppaṭividdhaṁ paññāya tathā tathā so tasmiṁ dhamme atthappaṭisaṁvedī
analyzed: yathā yathā āvuso bhikkhuno aññataram samādhi nimittam suggahitam hoti su manasikata  su upadhāritam su paṭividdham paññāya tathā tathā so tasmin dhamme attha ppaṭisavedī
translated: As he has taken up a meditation subject well, has given it proper attention,
has properly penetrated it with wisdom, he experiences the meaning and experiences the Dhamma in this very life.

original: Tassa atthappaṭisaṁvedino dhammappaṭisaṁvedino pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.🔽Idaṁ pañcamaṁ vimuttāyatanaṁ.
analyzed: tassa attha paṭisavedinaḥ dhamma paṭisavedinaḥ pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati  idam pañcamam vimutta āyatana
translated: This is the fifth opening to Nibbāna.
These are the five dhammas that should be directly known.
• “Which five dhammas should be realized?
Five aggregates:

analyzed: sīla kkhandho samādhi kkhandho paññā kkhandho vimutti kkhandho vimutti ñāṇa dassana kkhandho
translated: the form aggregate, the feeling aggregate, the perception aggregate, the fabrications aggregate, the consciousness aggregate.
These are the five dhammas that should be realized.

original: Iti ime paññāsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
analyzed: iti ime paññāsa dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā
translated: “These fifty dhammas—true, genuine, real, not unreal, not otherwise—have been rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata.
• “Monks, there are these six dhammas that are very helpful.

original: Cha dhammā bahukārā …pe… cha dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: cha dhammā bahu kārā pe cha dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: There are these six dhammas that are very helpful, six dhammas that are skillful, six dhammas that are to be developed, six dhammas that are to be comprehended, six dhammas that are to be abandoned, six dhammas that are on the side of decline, six dhammas that are on the side of distinction, six dhammas that are hard to penetrate, and six dhammas that should be made to arise.
• “Which six dhammas are very helpful?
Six ways of attending to the Teaching:

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca,
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhuno mettam kāya kammam paccupaṭṭhitam hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ca iva rahaḥ ca
translated: Here, a bhikkhu is friendly and compassionate towards his companions in the holy life, out of esteem for them, and he has compassion for them, is unostentatious, and has a sense of conscience.

original: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ …pe… ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhuno mettaṁ manokammaṁ …pe… ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattati  puna capare āvuso bhikkhunaḥ mettam vacī kammam pe ekībhāvāya savattati  puna capare āvuso bhikkhunaḥ mettam mano kammam pe ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This is a quality that creates love and respect, that leads to helpfulness, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi,
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu ye te lābhāḥ dhammikāḥ dhamma laddhāḥ antamasaḥ patta pariyāpanna mattam pi
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu is friendly and compassionate in speech towards his companions in the holy life, out of esteem for them, and he has compassion for them, is unostentatious, and has a sense of conscience.

original: tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī,
analyzed: tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhatta bhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇa bhogī
translated: This is a quality that creates love and respect, that leads to helpfulness, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.🔽“Again, a bhikkhu is friendly and compassionate in mind towards his companions in the holy life, out of esteem for them, and he has compassion for them, is unostentatious, and has a sense of conscience.

analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ pe ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This is a quality that creates love and respect, that leads to helpfulness, to non-dispute, to concord, and to unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu, yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni a kammāsāni
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu does not enjoy sensual pleasures, is not intent on them, does not welcome them, and does not have a distorted perception of them as pleasing.

original: bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni, tathārūpesu sīlesu🔽sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo
analyzed: bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhi savattanikāni tathārūpesu sīlesu  sīla sāmañña gataḥ viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ca iva raho ca ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyo
translated: and are conducive to concentration,🔽he dwells, in accordance with that Dhamma, both in public and in private, with his companions in the spiritual life, being one who speaks the Dhamma. This Dhamma is endearing…🔽

He lives with his fellows in the right way, both in public and in private, in accordance with the Dhamma and the Monastic Law. This is a quality that creates affection and respect… that leads to inclusion, non-dispute, harmony, and unity.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca,
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu yā ayam diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkha kkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmañña gataḥ viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ca iva raho ca
translated: And further, he has the view of the noble ones that leads to awakening and crossing over from the round of rebirths, and he lives with his fellows in the right way, both in public and in private, in accordance with that view.

original: ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo, saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo sāraṇīyaḥ piya karaṇaḥ garu karaṇaḥ saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya savattati
translated: This is a quality that creates affection and respect… that leads to inclusion, non-dispute, harmony, and unity.
These six things are very helpful.
• “Which six things should be developed?
Six recollections:

original: buddhānussati, dhammānussati, saṅghānussati, sīlānussati, cāgānussati, devatānussati.
analyzed: buddha anussati dhamma anussati saṅgha anussati sīla anussati cāga anussati devatā anussati
translated: the recollection of the Buddha, the recollection of the Dhamma, the recollection of the Sangha, the recollection of virtue, the recollection of generosity, and the recollection of the gods.
These six things should be developed.
• “Which six things should be comprehended?
The six internal sense spheres:

original: cakkhāyatanaṁ, sotāyatanaṁ, ghānāyatanaṁ, jivhāyatanaṁ, kāyāyatanaṁ, manāyatanaṁ.
analyzed: cakkhāyatana sotāyatana ghānāyatana jivhāyatana kāyāyatana manāyatana
translated: the sense sphere of the eye, the sense sphere of the ear, the sense sphere of the nose, the sense sphere of the tongue, the sense sphere of the body, the sense sphere of the mind.
These six dhammas should be comprehended.
• “Which six dhammas should be abandoned?
The six classes of craving:

original: rūpataṇhā, saddataṇhā, gandhataṇhā, rasataṇhā, phoṭṭhabbataṇhā, dhammataṇhā.
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā sadda taṇhā gandha taṇhā rasa taṇhā phoṭṭhabba taṇhā dhamma taṇhā
translated: craving for form, craving for sound, craving for smell, craving for taste, craving for tactile sensation, craving for ideas.
These six dhammas should be abandoned.
• “Which six dhammas are on the side of decline?
Six types of disrespect:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso. Dhamme …pe… saṅghe … sikkhāya … appamāde … paṭisanthāre agāravo viharati appatisso.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu satthari agāravaḥ viharati appatissaḥ dhamme pe saṅghe sikkhāya appamāde paṭisanthāre agāravaḥ viharati appatissaḥ
translated: There is the case, friends, where a monk dwells without respect or deference for the Teacher. … for the Dhamma … for the Saṅgha … for the training … for heedfulness … for welcoming manners.
These six dhammas are on the side of decline.
• “Which six dhammas are on the side of distinction?
Six types of respect:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu satthari sagāravo viharati sappatisso. Dhamme …pe… saṅghe … sikkhāya … appamāde … paṭisanthāre sagāravo viharati sappatisso.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu satthari sa gāravaḥ viharati sappatissaḥ dhamme pe saṅghe sikkhāya appamāde paṭisanthāre sa gāravaḥ viharati sappatissaḥ
translated: There is the case, friends, where a monk dwells with respect & deference for the Teacher. … for the Dhamma … for the Saṅgha … for the training … for heedfulness … for welcoming manners.
These six dhammas are conducive to distinction.
• “Which six dhammas are hard to penetrate?
Six properties of release:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu evaṁ vadeyya:🔽‘mettā hi kho me, cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā,
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu evam vadeyya  mettā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: There is the case, friends, where a monk might say,

original: atha ca pana me byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me byāpādaḥ cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: ‘Although goodwill has been developed, pursued, handed the reins, taken as a basis, steadied, consolidated, & well undertaken by me as my awareness-release, still ill will keeps overpowering my mind.’

original: So ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: He should be told, ‘Don’t say that. You shouldn’t speak in that way. Don’t misrepresent the Blessed One, for it’s not right to misrepresent the Blessed One, and the Blessed One wouldn’t say that.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ āvuso anavakāso yaṁ mettāya cetovimuttiyā bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam mettāya cetovimuttiyāḥ bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya
translated: It’s impossible, there is no way that—when goodwill has been developed, pursued, handed the reins, taken as a basis, steadied, consolidated, & well undertaken as an awareness-release—🔽ill will would still keep overpowering the mind.

original: Atha ca panassa byāpādo cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa byāpādaḥ cittam pariyādāya ṭhassati iti na etam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: That possibility doesn’t exist, for this is the escape from ill will: goodwill as an awareness-release.’

original: Nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, byāpādassa, yadidaṁ mettācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam heto āvuso byāpādassa yat idam mettā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For this is the escape from ill will, friends, namely, the liberation of the mind through loving-kindness.’

analyzed: idha pana āvuso bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, friends, a bhikkhu might say:

original: ‘karuṇā hi kho me cetovimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā.
analyzed: karuṇā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bahulīkatā yā anīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā su samāraddhā
translated: ‘Although I develop the liberation of the mind through compassion,

original: Atha ca pana me vihesā cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me vihesā cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: still ill will torments me.’

original: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo, ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi …pe…
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi pe
translated: He should be told: ‘Do not say so, friend. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent the Blessed One. The Blessed One would not speak thus.

original: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, vihesāya, yadidaṁ karuṇācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam heto āvuso vihesāya yat idam karuṇā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For this is the escape from ill will, friend, namely, the liberation of the mind through compassion.’

analyzed: idha pana āvuso bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, friends, a bhikkhu might say:

analyzed: muditā hi khalu me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā pe
translated: ‘Although I develop the liberation of the mind through appreciative joy,

original: atha ca pana me arati cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me arati cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: still discontent torments me.’

analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca pe
translated: He should be told: ‘Do not say so, friend. Do not misrepresent the Blessed One, for it is not right to misrepresent the Blessed One. The Blessed One would not speak thus.

original: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, aratiyā, yadidaṁ muditācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam heto āvuso aratiyāḥ yat idam muditā cetaḥ vimuttī iti
translated: For this is the escape from discontent, friend, namely, the liberation of the mind through appreciative joy.’

analyzed: idha pana āvuso bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “Here, friends, a bhikkhu might say:

analyzed: upekkhā hi kho me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā pe
translated: ‘I’ve developed the mind-deliverance of equanimity, and I’ve made it familiar, given it a grounding, settled it by meditation, and steadied it with practice,

original: atha ca pana me rāgo cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me rāgaḥ cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: yet still lust invades my mind and remains.’

analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca pe
translated: He should be told, ‘Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Blessed One, for it’s not right to misrepresent the Blessed One, and the Blessed One wouldn’t say that.

original: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, rāgassa yadidaṁ upekkhācetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam heto āvuso rāgassa yat idam upekkhā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For the escape in this case, friend, is the mind-deliverance of equanimity.’

analyzed: idha pana āvuso bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “A monk might say,

analyzed: animittā hi khalu me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā pe
translated: ‘I’ve developed the mind-deliverance with no-sign, and I’ve made it familiar, given it a grounding, settled it by meditation, and steadied it with practice,

original: atha ca pana me nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ hotī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me nimitta anusāri viññāṇam hoti iti
translated: yet still my consciousness follows the signs of forms.’

analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca pe
translated: He should be told, ‘Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Blessed One, for it’s not right to misrepresent the Blessed One, and the Blessed One wouldn’t say that.

original: nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṁ yadidaṁ animittā cetovimuttī’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam heto āvuso sabba nimittānam yat idam animittā cetaḥ vimutti iti
translated: For the escape in this case, friend, is the mind-deliverance with no-sign.’

analyzed: idha pana āvuso bhikkhu evam vadeyya
translated: “A monk might say,

original: ‘asmīti kho me vigataṁ, ayamahamasmīti na samanupassāmi,
analyzed: asmi iti kho me vigata ayam aham asmi iti na samanupassāmi
translated: ‘I’ve abandoned the conceit “I am,” and I don’t assume “I am this.”

original: atha ca pana me vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhatī’ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me vicikicchā kathaṅkathā sallam cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhati iti
translated: Yet still the dart of uncertainty & doubt invades my mind and remains.’

original: So: ‘mā hevan’tissa vacanīyo ‘māyasmā evaṁ avaca, mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi, na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ, na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya.
analyzed: saḥ mā hevantissa vacanīyaḥ mā ayasmai evam avaca mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi na hi sādhu bhagavataḥ na hi bhagavā evam vadeyya
translated: He should be told, ‘Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Blessed One, for it’s not right to misrepresent him. The Blessed One would never say such a thing.

original: Aṭṭhānametaṁ, āvuso, anavakāso yaṁ asmīti vigate ayamahamasmīti asamanupassato.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ete āvuso anavakāsaḥ yam asmi iti vigate ayam aham asmi iti a samanupassato
translated: It’s impossible, friend, it cannot happen that when ‘I am’ has been abandoned, the view ‘I am’ has been abandoned, the view ‘I will be’ does not occur.

original: Atha ca panassa vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallaṁ cittaṁ pariyādāya ṭhassati, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: atha ca panassa vicikicchā kathaṅkathā sallam cittam pariyādāya na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: But it’s possible that the dart of doubt & uncertainty might occupy his mind.

original: Nissaraṇaṁ hetaṁ, āvuso, vicikicchākathaṅkathāsallassa, yadidaṁ asmimānasamugghāto’ti.
analyzed: nissaraṇam heto āvuso vicikicchā kathaṅkathā sallassa yat idam
translated: But that’s the escape from the dart of doubt & uncertainty, namely, the uprooting of conceit ‘I am.’
These six dhammas are hard to penetrate.

analyzed: katame cha dhammā uppādetabbā  satata vihārā
translated: • “Which six dhammas should be made to arise?

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.🔽Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…🔽ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …🔽jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na iva sumanaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajānaḥ  sotena saddam sutvā pe  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā  jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: Six abidings: There is the case, friends, where a monk, having seen a form with the eye, is neither gladdened nor saddened, but remains equanimous, mindful, & alert.

Having heard a sound with the ear… Having smelled an odor with the nose… Having tasted a flavor with the tongue… Having felt a tactile sensation with the body…🔽Having cognized an idea with the intellect, he is neither gladdened nor saddened, but remains equanimous, mindful, & alert.

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na iva su manaḥ hoti na dummanaḥ upekkhakaḥ viharati sataḥ sampajāno
translated: When he has known with the mind a mind that is free from hate, he does not become excited …
These six dhammas should be developed.
“Which six dhammas should be comprehended?
Six unsurpassed things:

original: dassanānuttariyaṁ, savanānuttariyaṁ, lābhānuttariyaṁ, sikkhānuttariyaṁ, pāricariyānuttariyaṁ, anussatānuttariyaṁ.
analyzed: dassana anuttariya savana anuttariya lābha anuttariya sikkhā anuttariya pāricariya anuttariya anussata anuttariya
translated: the unsurpassed seeing, the unsurpassed hearing, the unsurpassed gain, the unsurpassed training, the unsurpassed service, the unsurpassed mindfulness.
These six dhammas should be comprehended.
“Which six dhammas should be realized?
Six kinds of direct knowledge:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu anekavihitaṁ iddhividhaṁ paccanubhoti—ekopi hutvā bahudhā hoti,🔽bahudhāpi hutvā eko hoti; āvibhāvaṁ tirobhāvaṁ; tirokuṭṭaṁ tiropākāraṁ tiropabbataṁ🔽asajjamāno gacchati seyyathāpi ākāse; pathaviyāpi ummujjanimujjaṁ karoti seyyathāpi
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu aneka vihitam iddhividham paccanubhoti ekaḥ api hutvā bahudhā hoti  bahudhā api hutvā ekaḥ hoti āvi bhāvam tiro bhāva tirokuṭṭam tiro upākāram tiro pabbata  a sajjamānaḥ gacchati sā iyathā api ākāse pathaviyā api ummujja nimujjam karoti sā iyathā api
translated: Here, with his mind thus concentrated, a bhikkhu wields the various kinds of spiritual power: having been one, he becomes many;

original: udake; udakepi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathāpi pathaviyaṁ; ākāsepi pallaṅkena kamati
analyzed: udake udake pi abhijjamāne gacchati seyyathā api pathaviye ākāse pi pallaṅkena kamati
translated: having been many, he becomes one; he appears and vanishes; he goes unhindered through a wall, through a rampart, through a mountain as though through space; he dives in and out of the earth as though through water; he goes on unbroken water as though on earth; seated cross-legged he travels through space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes even the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; he exercises mastery with the body as far as the brahma world.

original: seyyathāpi pakkhī sakuṇo; imepi candimasūriye evaṁmahiddhike evaṁmahānubhāve pāṇinā
analyzed: seyyathā api pakkhī sakuṇaḥ ime api candima sūriye eva mahiddhike eva mahā anubhāve pāṇinā
translated: and he can touch and stroke the moon and sun, so mighty and powerful,

original: parāmasati parimajjati; yāva brahmalokāpi kāyena vasaṁ vatteti.
analyzed: parāmasati parimajjati yāva brahma lokā api kāyena vasam vatta iti
translated: and exercise the various kinds of psychic power: having been one, he becomes many; having been many, he becomes one; he appears and disappears; he goes unhindered through walls, through enclosures, through mountains, as though through space; he dives in and out of the earth as though in water; he goes on unbroken water as though on earth; seated cross-legged he travels through space like a bird; with his hand he touches and strokes even as far as the world of Brahmā.

original: Dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkantamānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca, ye dūre santike ca.
analyzed: dibbāya sotadhātuyā visuddhāya atikkanta mānusikāya ubho sadde suṇāti dibbe ca mānuse ca ye dūre santike ca
translated: With the divine ear element, which is purified and surpasses the human, he hears both kinds of sounds, the divine and the human, those that are far as well as near.🔽He understands the minds of other beings, of other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind.

original: Parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti,🔽sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ sarāgaṁ cittanti pajānāti …pe…
analyzed: para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ paricca pajānāti  sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti pe
translated: He understands a mind with passion as a mind with passion,

original: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ avimuttaṁ cittanti pajānāti.
analyzed: a vimuttam vā cittam a vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: and a mind without passion as a mind without passion;

original: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati jātim pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: he remembers his manifold past abodes with their aspects and details.

original: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti …pe…
analyzed: dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti pe
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and arising: base and noble, well favored and ill favored, to happy and unhappy destinations as kamma directs them. He understands how beings pass on according to their kamma, …

original: Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati
translated: Through the destruction of the taints, he realizes for himself with direct knowledge, in this very life, the taintless liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, and having entered upon it, he dwells in it.
These are the six dhammas that should be realized.

original: Iti ime saṭṭhi dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
analyzed: iti ime saṭṭhi dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā
translated: These sixty dhammas—true, genuine, real, not unreal, not otherwise—have been rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata.
Seven dhammas,

original: Satta dhammā bahukārā …pe… satta dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: satta dhammā bahu kārā pe satta dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: Seven dhammas are very helpful, seven dhammas should be developed, seven dhammas should be comprehended, seven dhammas should be abandoned, seven dhammas are on the side of decline, seven dhammas are on the side of distinction, seven dhammas are hard to penetrate, and seven dhammas should be made to arise.
What are the seven dhammas that are very helpful?
There are these seven treasures:

original: saddhādhanaṁ, sīladhanaṁ, hiridhanaṁ, ottappadhanaṁ, sutadhanaṁ, cāgadhanaṁ, paññādhanaṁ.
analyzed: saddhā dhana sīla dhana hiri dhana ottappa dhana suta dhana cāga dhana paññā dhana
translated: the treasures of conviction, virtue, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
These are the seven dhammas that are very helpful.
What are the seven dhammas that should be developed?
There are these seven factors of awakening:

original: satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.
analyzed: sati sambojjhaṅaḥ dhamma vicaya sambojjhaṅgaḥ vīriya sambojjhaṅgaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgaḥ passaddhi sambojjhaṅgaḥ samādhi sambojjhaṅgaḥ upekkhā sambojjhaṅgaḥ
translated: the factor of complete awakening that is mindfulness, the factor of complete awakening that is investigation of (the nature of) things, the factor of complete awakening that is energy, the factor of complete awakening that is rapture, the factor of complete awakening that is calm, the factor of complete awakening that is concentration, the factor of complete awakening that is equanimity.
These seven dhammas should be developed.
Which seven dhammas should be comprehended?
There are seven abodes of consciousness:

original: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api manussāḥ ekacce ca devāḥ ekacce ca vinipātikā
translated: There are, friends, beings who have various bodies and various ideas, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the lower worlds.
This is the first abode of consciousness.

original: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api devāḥ brahmakāyikā paṭhama abhinibbattā
translated: There are, friends, beings who have various bodies but have one and the same idea, such as the gods who are the Refulgent Devas who have attained the first abhinibbāna.
This is the second abode of consciousness.

original: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api devāḥ ābhassarā
translated: There are, friends, beings who have one and the same body but have various ideas, such as the gods who are the Streaming Radiance Devas.
This is the third abode of consciousness.

original: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api devā subha kiṇhā
translated: There are, friends, beings who have one and the same body and have one and the same idea, such as the gods who are the Recognised Devas.
This is the fourth abode of consciousness.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā …pe… ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā pe anantaḥ ākāso ti ākāsa anañca āyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, the passing away of perceptions of sensory impact, and non-attention to perceptions of diversity, ‘space is infinite,’ arrive at the dimension of the infinitude of space.
This is the fifth abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbasas ākāsānañca āyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of the dimension of the infinitude of space, ‘consciousness is infinite,’ arrive at the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness.
This is the sixth abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbasas viññāṇam ca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, ‘there is nothing,’ arrive at the dimension of nothingness.
This is the seventh abode of beings.
These seven dhammas should be comprehended.
• “Which seven dhammas should be abandoned?
Seven underlying tendencies:

original: kāmarāgānusayo, paṭighānusayo, diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo, mānānusayo, bhavarāgānusayo, avijjānusayo.
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayo paṭigha anusayaḥ diṭṭha anusayaḥ vicikicchā anusayaḥ māna anusayaḥ bhava rāga anusayaḥ avijjā anusayaḥ
translated: the underlying tendency to sensual desire, the underlying tendency to aversion, the underlying tendency to views, the underlying tendency to doubt, the underlying tendency to conceit, the underlying tendency to passion for becoming, the underlying tendency to ignorance.
These seven dhammas should be abandoned.
• “Which seven dhammas are on the side of decline?
Seven unskillful dhammas:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu assaddhaḥ hoti ahirikaḥ hoti anottappī hoti appassutaḥ hoti kusītaḥ hoti muṭṭha sati hoti duppaññaḥ hoti
translated: There is a monk who is without conviction, without a sense of shame, without compunction, uneducated, lazy, forgetful, and without concentration.
These seven dhammas are on the side of decline.
• “Which seven dhammas are on the side of distinction?
Seven dhammas that are rightly expounded:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, paññavā hoti.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu saddhaḥ hoti hirimā hoti ottappī hoti bahu ssutaḥ hoti āraddha vīriyaḥ hoti upaṭṭhita sati hoti paññavā hoti
translated: There is a monk who is conviction, conscience, shame, learned, ardent, established in mindfulness, and discerning.
These seven dhammas are on the side of distinction.
• “Which seven dhammas are hard to penetrate?
Seven qualities of a person of integrity:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu dhammaññū ca hoti atthaññū ca attaññū ca mattaññū ca kālaññū ca parisaññū ca puggalaññū ca.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu dhamma ññū ca hoti attha ññū ca atta ññū ca matta ññū ca kāla ññū ca parisa ññū ca puggala ññū ca
translated: There is the case, friends, where a monk knows dhamma, knows the meaning, knows himself, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows composure, & knows the assembly.
These seven dhammas are hard to penetrate.
• “Which seven dhammas should be made to arise?
Seven perceptions:

original: aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā.
analyzed: anicca saññā anatta saññā asubha saññā ādīnava saññā pahāna saññā virāga saññā nirodha saññā
translated: the perception of inconstancy, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of abandoning, the perception of dispassion, the perception of cessation.
These seven dhammas should be developed.
• “Which seven dhammas should be comprehended?

original: Satta niddasavatthūni—🔽idhāvuso, bhikkhu sikkhāsamādāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca sikkhāsamādāne avigatapemo.
analyzed: satta niddasa vatthūni  idha āvuso bhikkhu sikkhā samādāne tibba chandaḥ hoti āyatim ca sikkhā samādāne a vigata pemo
translated: Seven grounds for taunts:🔽There is the case, friends, where a monk is not consummate in virtue, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is not consummate in concentration, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is not consummate in discernment, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.

original: Dhammanisantiyā tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca dhammanisantiyā avigatapemo.🔽Icchāvinaye tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca icchāvinaye avigatapemo.🔽Paṭisallāne tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca paṭisallāne avigatapemo.
analyzed: dhamma nisantiyā tibba chandaḥ hoti āyatiñca dhamma nisantiyā avigata pemo  icchā vinaye hoti āyatiñca icchā vinaye a vigata pemo  paṭisallāne tibba chandaḥ hoti āyatim ca paṭisallāne a vigata pemo
translated: He is not consummate in relinquishment, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is not consummate in wisdom, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is not consummate in freedom, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.

original: Vīriyārambhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca vīriyārambhe avigatapemo.🔽Satinepakke tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca satinepakke avigatapemo.
analyzed: vīriya ārambhe tibba chandaḥ hoti āyatiñca vīriya ārambhe a vigata pemo  sati nepakke tibba chandaḥ hoti āyatim ca sati nepakke a vigata pemo
translated: He is not consummate in the knowledge & vision of freedom, but he is consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽• “Seven grounds for taunts:🔽There is the case, friends, where a monk is consummate in virtue, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is consummate in concentration, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is consummate in discernment, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.

original: Diṭṭhipaṭivedhe tibbacchando hoti, āyatiñca diṭṭhipaṭivedhe avigatapemo.
analyzed: diṭṭhi paṭivedhe tibba chandaḥ hoti āyatim ca diṭṭhi paṭivedhe a vigata pemo
translated: He is consummate in relinquishment, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is consummate in wisdom, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is consummate in freedom, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.🔽He is consummate in the knowledge & vision of freedom, but he is not consummate in terms of the basics of the holy life.
These seven dhammas should be directly known.
• “Which seven dhammas should be realized?

Seven powers of one whose effluents are ended:🔽“There is the case, friends, where a monk whose effluents are ended has seen all conditioned phenomena as they actually are with correct wisdom as impermanent.🔽“Whatever there is of form, feeling, perception, fabrications, & consciousness,

original: idhāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
analyzed: idha āvuso khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārāḥ yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: he has seen all of them as they actually are with correct wisdom as impermanent.🔽This is a power of a monk whose effluents are ended, depending on which he claims the place of safety, the place of shelter, the place of refuge, the place with nothing higher: ‘I am one whose effluents are ended.🔽“And further, the monk whose effluents are ended has seen all conditioned phenomena as they actually are with correct wisdom as stressful.🔽Whatever there is of form, feeling, perception, fabrications, & consciousness,

original: Yaṁpāvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya
analyzed: yapa āvuso khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aniccato sabbe saṅkhārāḥ yathābhūtam sammappaññāya
translated: he has seen all of them as they actually are with correct wisdom as stressful.🔽This is a power of a monk whose effluents are ended, depending on which he claims the place of safety, the place of shelter, the place of refuge, the place with nothing higher: ‘I am one whose effluents are ended.

original: sudiṭṭhā honti, idampi khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balaṁ hoti, yaṁ balaṁ āgamma khīṇāsavo
analyzed: su diṭṭhāḥ honti idam api khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno balam hoti yam balam āgamma khīṇāsavaḥ
translated: “And further, the monk whose effluents are ended has seen all conditioned phenomena as they actually are with correct wisdom as not-self.🔽Whatever there is of form, feeling, perception, fabrications, & consciousness,🔽he has seen all of them as they actually are with correct wisdom as not-self.

original: bhikkhu āsavānaṁ khayaṁ paṭijānāti: ‘khīṇā me āsavā’ti.
analyzed: bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayam paṭijānāti khīṇā me āsavā ati
translated: This is a power of a monk whose effluents are ended, depending on which he claims the place of safety, the place of shelter, the place of refuge, the place with nothing higher: ‘I am one whose effluents are ended.🔽“And further, the monk whose effluents are ended has seen all conditioned phenomena as they actually are with correct wisdom as subject to cessation.🔽Whatever there is of form, feeling, perception, fabrications, & consciousness,

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aṅgārakāsūpamā kāmā yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhā honti.
analyzed: puna capare āvuso khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno aṅgārakāsu upamā kāmāḥ yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭhāḥ honti
translated: he has seen all of them as they actually are with correct wisdom as subject to cessation.

This is a power of a monk whose effluents are ended, depending on which he claims the place of safety, the place of shelter, the place of refuge, the place with nothing higher: ‘I am one whose effluents are ended.🔽“And further, the monk whose effluents are ended has seen all conditioned phenomena as they actually are with correct wisdom as having the nature of fading away.🔽Whatever there

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno vivekaninnaṁ cittaṁ hoti vivekapoṇaṁ vivekapabbhāraṁ vivekaṭṭhaṁ nekkhammābhirataṁ byantībhūtaṁ sabbaso āsavaṭṭhāniyehi dhammehi.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno viveka ninnam cittam hoti viveka poṇam viveka pabbhāram vivekaṭṭham nekkhamma abhiratam byantībhūtam sabbasas āsava ṭṭhāniyehi dhammehi
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu whose taints are destroyed directs his mind to his own relinquishment of the taints.
He understands thus: ‘I have relinquished the taints in such a way that they do not remain connected with me or cling to me.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.
analyzed: puna capare āvuso khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno cattāro satipaṭṭhānāḥ bhāvitāḥ honti su bhāvitā
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu whose taints are destroyed develops the four establishments of mindfulness…
He understands thus: ‘I have relinquished the taints in such a way that they do not remain connected with me or cling to me.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pañcindriyāni bhāvitāni honti subhāvitāni.
analyzed: puna capare āvuso khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pañca indriyāni bhāvitāni honti su bhāvitāni
translated: “Again, a bhikkhu whose taints are destroyed develops the five spiritual faculties…
He understands thus: ‘I have relinquished the taints in such a way that they do not remain connected with me or cling to me.’

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā honti subhāvitā.

translated: This is the second cause and condition that leads to the acquiring of the as-yet-unacquired discernment that is basic to the holy life, and to the increase, plenitude, development, and fulfillment of that which has already been acquired.

translated: This is the third cause and condition that leads to the acquiring of the as-yet-unacquired discernment that is basic to the holy life, and to the increase, plenitude, development, and fulfillment of that which has already been acquired.

Eight grounds for laziness:

analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhunā kammam kātabbam hoti

translated: ‘I will have to do this work. But when I’m doing this work, my body will become tired. Let me lie down.’

translated: “Then there is the case where a monk has done some work.

translated: ‘There is the case where a monk, walking for alms in a village or town, gets as much coarse or refined food as he would’ve liked,
and he thinks,

Eight emancipations:
Having form, one sees forms.
This is the first emancipation.

original: Ajjhattaṁ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati.
analyzed: ajjhattam arūpa saññī ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati
translated: Not perceiving forms internally, one sees forms externally.
This is the second emancipation.
One is focused only on being beautiful.
This is the third emancipation.

original: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsānañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the complete transcending of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of resistance, and not attending to perceptions of multiplicity, ‘space is infinite,’ one enters & remains in the dimension of the infinitude of space.
This is the fourth emancipation.

original: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of space, ‘consciousness is infinite,’ one enters & remains in the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness.
This is the fifth emancipation.

original: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, ‘there is nothing,’ one enters & remains in the dimension of nothingness.
This is the sixth emancipation.

original: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Having completely transcended the base of nothingness, he enters & remains in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
This is the seventh release.

original: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbasas nevasaññā nāsañña āyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati
translated: “Having completely transcended the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, he enters & remains in the cessation of perception & feeling.

original: Ayaṁ aṭṭhamo vimokkho.🔽Ime aṭṭha dhammā sacchikātabbā.

translated: “These are the eighty dhammas that are rightly expounded by the Blessed One—the one who knows, the one who sees, the Worthy One, rightly self-awakened.
Nine Dhammas

original: Nava dhammā bahukārā …pe… nava dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: nava dhammā bahu kārā pe nava dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: “Nine dhammas, friends, are very helpful. Nine dhammas should be developed. Nine dhammas should be comprehended. Nine dhammas should be abandoned. Nine dhammas are on the side of decline. Nine dhammas are on the side of distinction. Nine dhammas are hard to penetrate. Nine dhammas should be made to arise. Nine dhammas should be directly known. Nine dhammas should be realized.

“And which nine dhammas are very helpful?🔽Nine forms of initiative: There is the case, friends, where a monk has conviction, is convinced of the Tathāgata’s awakening: ‘Indeed, the Blessed One is worthy & rightly self-awakened, consummate in clear-knowing & conduct, well-gone, an expert with regard to the cosmos, unexcelled trainer of people fit to be tamed, teacher of devas & human beings, awakened, blessed.’🔽“He is free from illness & discomfort, endowed with good digestion—not too cold, not too hot, of moderate strength—fit for exertion.

original: Nava yonisomanasikāramūlakā dhammā, yonisomanasikaroto pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa
analyzed: nava yoni soma nasikāra mūlakā dhammā yoni soma nasikaroto pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa
translated: “He is neither fraudulent nor deceitful. He declares himself to the Teacher or to his observant companions in the holy life in line with what he actually is.🔽“He is content with any old robe cloth at all.🔽“He is content with any old almsfood at all.🔽“He is content with any old lodging at all.

translated: “He is gratified with any old medicinal requisites at all.

Nine factors for exertion:

original: sīlavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, cittavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, diṭṭhivisuddhi🔽pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhi pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgaṁ, maggāmaggañāṇadassanavisuddhi
analyzed: citta visuddhi pārisuddhi padhāniyaṅga diṭṭhi visuddhi  kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhi pārisuddhi padhāniyaṅga magga amagga ñāṇa dassana visuddhi
translated: The factor of exertion for purification of virtue, the factor of exertion for purification of mind, the factor of exertion for purification of view,🔽the factor of exertion for purification via overcoming doubt about the Dhamma, the factor of exertion for purification via knowledge & vision of what is & isn’t the path,

analyzed: pārisuddhi padhāniyaṅga paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi
translated: the factor of exertion for purification via knowledge & vision of the way, the factor of exertion for purification via knowledge & vision,

translated: the factor of exertion for purification of discernment, the factor of exertion for purification of release.
These nine dhammas should be developed.

Nine abodes of beings:

original: santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi manussā ekacce ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api manussāḥ ekacce ca devāḥ ekacce ca vinipātikā
translated: There are beings who have different bodies and different perceptions, such as human beings, some gods, and some beings in the lower realms.
This is the first abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā brahmakāyikā paṭhamābhinibbattā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api devāḥ brahmakāyikā paṭhama abhinibbattā
translated: There are beings who have different bodies but the same perception, such as the gods of the Brahma-order who are newly reborn in the first absorption.
This is the second abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā ābhassarā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api devāḥ ābhassarā
translated: There are beings who have the same body but different perceptions, such as the gods of Streaming Radiance.
This is the third abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, seyyathāpi devā subhakiṇhā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ seyyathā api devā subha kiṇhā
translated: There are beings who have the same body and the same perception, such as the gods of Refulgent Glory.
This is the fourth abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā asaññino appaṭisaṁvedino, seyyathāpi devā asaññasattā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattāḥ a saññinaḥ a paṭisavedinaḥ seyyathā api devāḥ a sañña sattā
translated: There are beings who are without perception or feeling, such as the gods who are free from perception and feeling.
This is the fifth abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṁ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṁ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbasas rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam amanasikārā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ ti ākāsa anañca āyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, and not attending to perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, have passed on to rebirth in the base of infinite space.
This is the sixth abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbasas ākāsānañca āyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of the dimension of the infinitude of space, ‘Infinite consciousness is the factor of this,’ enter & remain in the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness.
This is the seventh abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbasas viññāṇam ca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, ‘There is nothing at all,’ enter & remain in the dimension of nothingness.
This is the eighth abode of beings.

original: Santāvuso, sattā sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagā.
analyzed: santi āvuso sattā sabbasas ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatana upagā
translated: There are beings who, with the complete surmounting of the dimension of nothingness, enter & remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
This is the ninth abode of beings.

Nine dhammas rooted in craving:

original: taṇhaṁ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṁ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṁ paṭicca vinicchayo,
analyzed: taṇham paṭicca pariyesanā pariyesanam paṭicca lābhaḥ lābham paṭicca vinicchayaḥ
translated: Craving dependent on acquisition, acquisition dependent on searching, searching dependent on craving, craving dependent on feeling, feeling dependent on contact, contact dependent on the six sense media, the six sense media dependent on name-&-form, name-&-form dependent on consciousness, consciousness dependent on fabrications.🔽Dependent on fabrications, consciousness comes into play.🔽Dependent on consciousness, name-&-form.🔽Dependent on name-&-form, the six sense media.🔽Dependent on the six sense media, contact.🔽Dependent on contact, feeling.

original: vinicchayaṁ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṁ paṭicca ajjhosānaṁ, ajjhosānaṁ paṭicca

original: pariggaho, pariggahaṁ paṭicca macchariyaṁ, macchariyaṁ paṭicca ārakkho, ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ

analyzed: daṇḍa ādāna sattha ādāna kalaha viggaha vivāda tuva tuva pesuñña musāvādāḥ aneke pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ sambhavanti

translated: ‘He is doing harm to people who are dear & pleasing to me,’ one generates resentment. …🔽‘He is going to do harm to people who are dear & pleasing to me,’ one generates resentment.🔽‘He has aided people who are not dear or pleasing to me,’ one generates resentment. …🔽‘He is aiding people who are not dear or pleasing to me,’ one generates resentment. …

These nine dhammas are on the side of decline.

Nine ways of settling arguments:

original: ‘anatthaṁ me acari, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;🔽‘anatthaṁ me carati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
analyzed: anattham me acari tam kuta ittha labbhāti āghātam paṭivineti  anattham me carati tam kuta ittha labbhāti āghātam paṭivineti
translated: ‘He has done me harm. But what can I expect? He’s human, like me.’🔽‘He’s doing me harm. But what can I expect? He’s human, like me.’

original: ‘anatthaṁ me carissati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
analyzed: anattham me carissati tam kuta ittha labbhāti āghātam paṭivineti
translated: ‘He will do me harm. But what can I expect? He’s human, like me.’

original: ‘piyassa me manāpassa anatthaṁ acari …pe…🔽anatthaṁ carati …pe…🔽anatthaṁ carissati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti;
analyzed: piyassa me manāpassa anattham acari pe  anattham carati pe  anattham carissati tam kuta ittha labbhāti āghātam paṭivineti
translated: ‘My loved one has done harm to someone I don’t like. But what can I expect? He’s human, like me.’🔽‘My loved one is doing harm to someone I don’t like. But what can I expect? He’s human, like me.’

analyzed: appiyassa me amanāpassa attham acari pe  carati pe

He’s human, like me.’🔽‘My loved one is doing good to someone I don’t like. But what can I expect? He’s human, like me.’

original: atthaṁ carissati, taṁ kutettha labbhā’ti āghātaṁ paṭivineti.
analyzed: attham carissati tam kuta ittha labbhāti āghātam paṭivineti

These nine things lead to distinction.
• “Which nine things are hard to penetrate?

original: Nava nānattā—🔽dhātunānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṁ, phassanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati
analyzed: nava nānattā  dhātu nānattam paṭicca uppajjati phassa nānatta phassa nānattam paṭicca uppajjati
translated: Nine kinds of diversity:

original: vedanānānattaṁ, vedanānānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṁ, saññānānattaṁ paṭicca
analyzed: vedanā nānatta vedanā nānattam paṭicca uppajjati saññā nānatta saññā nānattam paṭicca
translated: Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contact. Diversity of contact gives rise to diversity of feeling. Diversity of feeling gives rise to diversity of perception. Diversity of perception gives rise to diversity of intention. Diversity of intention gives rise to diversity of desire. Diversity of desire gives rise to diversity of passion. Diversity of passion gives rise to diversity of persons.

original: uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṁ, saṅkappanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṁ, chandanānattaṁ🔽paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṁ, pariḷāhanānattaṁ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṁ,
analyzed: uppajjati saṅkappa nānatta saṅkappa nānattam paṭicca uppajjati chanda nānatta chanda nānatta  paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāha nānatta pariḷāha nānattam paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanā nānatta
translated: The variety of thinking leads to the variety of intentions. The variety of intentions leads to the variety of desires.🔽The variety of desires leads to the variety of passions. The variety of passions leads to the variety of fevers.

analyzed: pariyesanā nānattam paṭicca uppajjati lābha nānattam
translated: The variety of fevers leads to the variety of searches. The variety of searches leads to the variety of gains.
These nine dhammas are hard to penetrate.
• “Which nine dhammas should be made to arise?
Nine perceptions:

original: asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhārepaṭikūlasaññā, sabbalokeanabhiratisaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā.
analyzed: asubha saññā maraṇa saññā āhāre paṭikūla saññā sabbaloke anabhirati saññā anicca saññā anicce dukkha saññā dukkhe anatta saññā pahāna saññā virāga saññā
translated: the perception of unattractiveness, the perception of death, the perception of the repulsiveness of food, the perception of non-delight in the entire world, the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in the impermanent, the perception of non-self in what is suffering, the perception of abandoning, the perception of dispassion.
These nine dhammas should be made to arise.
• “Which nine dhammas should be directly known?
Nine step-by-step dwellings:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: There is the case, friends, where a monk, quite secluded from sensuality, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters & remains in the first jhāna: rapture & pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought & evaluation.

original: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati  pītiyā ca virāgā pe tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhana…🔽With the fading away as well of rapture…he enters upon and abides in the third jhana…

original: Sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṁ samatikkamā …pe… ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sukhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati  sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā pe ākāsa ānañca āyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure and pain…he enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana…🔽With the complete surmounting of perceptions of form…he enters upon and abides in the base of infinite space…

original: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘anantaṁ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanam samatikkamma anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the complete surmounting of the base of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, he enters upon and abides in the base of infinite consciousness…

original: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma na atthi kiñci iti ākiñcaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati  sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanam samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the complete surmounting of the base of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing’, he enters upon and abides in the base of nothingness…🔽With the complete surmounting of the base of nothingness, he enters upon and abides in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Ime nava dhammā abhiññeyyā.
analyzed: sabbasas nevasaññā nāsañña āyatanam samatikkamma saññā vedayita nirodham upasampajja viharati  ime nava dhammā abhiññeyyā
translated: With the complete surmounting of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, he enters upon and abides in the cessation of perception and feeling.🔽These nine dhammas should be directly known.
• “Which nine dhammas should be realized?

original: Nava anupubbanirodhā—🔽paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa kāmasaññā niruddhā hoti,
analyzed: nava anupubba nirodhā  paṭhamam jhānam samāpannassa kāma saññā niruddhā hoti
translated: Nine cessations:🔽When you have attained the first absorption, perceptions of sensuality have ceased.

original: dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā niruddhā honti,🔽tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa pīti niruddhā hoti,
analyzed: dutiyam jhānam samāpannassa vitakka vicārāḥ niruddhāḥ honti  tatiyam jhānam samāpannassa pīti niruddhā hoti
translated: When you have attained the second absorption, directed thoughts and evaluations have ceased.🔽When you have attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ samāpannassa assāsapassāssā niruddhā honti,
analyzed: catuttham jhānam samāpannassa assāsa passāssāḥ niruddhāḥ honti
translated: When you have attained the fourth absorption, in-and-out breaths have ceased.

original: ākāsānañcāyatanaṁ samāpannassa rūpasaññā niruddhā hoti,🔽viññāṇañcāyatanaṁ samāpannassa ākāsānañcāyatanasaññā niruddhā hoti,
analyzed: ākāsānañcāyatanam samāpannassa rūpa saññā niruddhā hoti  viññāṇañcāyatanam samāpannassa ākāsānañcāyatana saññā niruddhā hoti
translated: When you have attained the dimension of the infinitude of space, the perception of forms has ceased.🔽When you have attained the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, the perception of the dimension of the infinitude of space has ceased.

original: ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samāpannassa viññāṇañcāyatanasaññā niruddhā hoti,🔽nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ samāpannassa ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā niruddhā hoti,
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpannassa viññāṇañcāyatana saññā niruddhā hoti  nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samāpannassa ākiñcaññāyatana saññā niruddhā hoti
translated: When you have attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness has ceased.🔽When you have attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.

original: saññāvedayitanirodhaṁ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti.
analyzed: saññā vedayita nirodham samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti
translated: When you have attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
These nine dhammas should be realized.

original: Iti ime navuti dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā.
analyzed: iti ime navuti dhammā bhūtā tacchā tathā avitathā anaññathā sammā tathāgatena abhisambuddhā
translated: These ninety dhammas are real, true, and accurate—not otherwise—and were rightly awakened to by the Tathāgata.
Ten dhammas

original: Dasa dhammā bahukārā …pe… dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā.
analyzed: dasa dhammā bahu kārā pe dasa dhammā sacchikātabbā
translated: Ten dhammas are very helpful, ten dhammas should be developed, ten dhammas should be comprehended, ten dhammas should be given up, ten dhammas should be realized.
What are the ten dhammas that are very helpful?
Ten qualities make you a refuge:

original: idhāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.🔽Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti …pe… sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu sīlavā hoti pātimokkha savara savutaḥ viharati ācāra gocara sampannaḥ aṇumattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu  yapāvuso bhikkhu sīlavā hoti pe sikkhati sikkhāpadesu
translated: A monastic is virtuous. They live restrained by the code of conduct, seeing danger in the slightest fault, and train in the training rules they’ve undertaken.

original: Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu bahussuto …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo nātha karaṇo  puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu bahu ssutaḥ pe diṭṭhiyā su paṭividdhā
translated: This is a quality that makes you a refuge.

analyzed: yapa āvuso bhikkhu bahu suto pe
translated: Furthermore, a monastic is learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and they point out a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
This is a quality that makes you a refuge.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto hoti kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu kalyāṇa mittaḥ hoti kalyāṇa sahāyaḥ kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ
translated: Furthermore, a monastic has good friends, good companions, good comrades.

analyzed: yapa āvuso bhikkhu pe kalyāṇa sampavaṅkaḥ
translated: When a monk is a good speaker, eloquent, skilled in speech, complete with the requisite skill in speech,

original: Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu suvaco hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgato, khamo padakkhiṇaggāhī anusāsaniṁ.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo nātha karaṇo  puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu suvacaḥ hoti sovacassakaraṇehi dhammehi samannāgataḥ khamaḥ padakkhiṇa ggāhī anusāsani
translated: that is a quality that gives protection.🔽“Again, a monk is easy to speak to, has a sense of conscience, is well-behaved, and receives instruction.
When a monk is easy to speak to, has a sense of conscience, is well-behaved, and receives instruction,

original: Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnaṁ uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tattha dakkho hoti analaso tatrupāyāya vīmaṁsāya samannāgato, alaṁ kātuṁ, alaṁ saṁvidhātuṁ.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo nātha karaṇo  puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu yāni tāni sabrahmacārīnam uccāvacāni kiṅkaraṇīyāni tattha dakkhaḥ hoti analasaḥ vīmasāya samannāgataḥ alam kātu alam savidhātu
translated: that is a quality that gives protection.🔽“Again, a monk is deft and diligent in attending to his fellows in the holy life, in various duties connected with the monastery, and in various duties connected with his robes, bowl, and the rest. He is capable of various kinds of work and is not lazy in his duties.

When a monk is deft and diligent in attending to his fellows in the holy life, in various duties connected with the monastery, and in various duties connected with his robes, bowl, and the rest, and is capable of various kinds of work and is not lazy in his duties,

original: Ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu dhammakāmo hoti piyasamudāhāro abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷārapāmojjo.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo nātha karaṇo  puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu dhamma kāmaḥ hoti piya samudāhāraḥ abhidhamme abhivinaye uḷāra pāmojjaḥ
translated: that is a quality that gives protection.🔽“Again, a monk is fond of the Dhamma, greatly delights in the Dhamma, loves to hear the Dhamma, delights in hearing the Dhamma.

analyzed: yapa āvuso bhikkhu pe uḷāra pāmojjo
translated: When a monk is fond of the Dhamma, greatly delights in the Dhamma, loves to hear the Dhamma, delights in hearing the Dhamma,
that is a quality that gives protection.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarehi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti itarītarehi cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārehi
translated: “And further, the monk is content with any old robe cloth at all, any old almsfood, any old lodging, any old medicinal requisites for curing sickness at all.🔽This is the second thing that is helpful.

“And further, the monk is adept at the various affairs—advisory, legal, or business—of the monks, adept at settling legal issues that have come up.🔽This is the third thing that is helpful.🔽“And further, the monk is energetic in abandoning unskillful qualities and in developing skillful qualities.
This is the fourth thing that is helpful.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu āraddhavīriyo viharati …pe… kusalesu dhammesu.
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu āraddha vīriyaḥ viharati pe kusalesu dhammesu
translated: “And further, the monk is mindful, endowed with heightened mindfulness & alertness, one who remembers & recollects what was done & said a long time ago.🔽This is the fifth thing that is helpful.
“And further, the monk is wise, endowed with the wisdom that discerns arising & passing away—noble, penetrating, leading to the right ending of stress.

original: ayampi dhammo nāthakaraṇo.🔽Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu satimā hoti, paramena satinepakkena samannāgato, cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
analyzed: ayam pi dhammo nātha karaṇo  puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu satimā hoti paramena sati nepakkena samannāgataḥ cirakatam pi cira bhāsitam pi saritā anussaritā
translated: This is the sixth thing that is helpful.🔽“And further, the monk is a good speaker, with a good delivery, possessing a good voice—one who gives discourses that are polished, clear, articulate, expressing well the meaning & the cause.🔽This is the seventh thing that is helpful.
“And further, the monk is a good friend, a good companion, a good comrade, one who initiates talk that is sobering, arousing, & leading to helpfulness, who keeps talk on these topics going.
This is the eighth thing that is helpful.

original: Puna caparaṁ, āvuso, bhikkhu paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato, ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.🔽Yaṁpāvuso, bhikkhu …pe…
analyzed: puna caparaḥ āvuso bhikkhu paññavā hoti udaya ttha gāminiyā paññāya samannāgataḥ ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkha kkhaya gāminiyā  yapa avuso bhikkhu pe
translated: “And further, the monk is a mediator, one who brings about settlements, who delights in, is devoted to, and persists in settling disputes that have arisen.

This is the ninth thing that is helpful.🔽“And further, the monk is a good person, one who teaches the Dhamma to others in detail as he has heard it and learned it.🔽This is the tenth thing that is helpful.
“These ten things are helpful.”
Which ten dhammas should be developed?
Ten kasiṇa bases:

original: pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṁ adho tiriyaṁ advayaṁ appamāṇaṁ.🔽Āpokasiṇameko sañjānāti …pe…🔽tejokasiṇameko sañjānāti …
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti uddham adhas tiriyam advayam appamāṇa  sañjānāti pe  tejaḥ kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti
translated: One perceives the earth kasiṇa above, below, across—unbroken, unbounded, and measureless.🔽One perceives the water kasiṇa …🔽One perceives the fire kasiṇa …

analyzed: vāyu kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti  nīla kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti
translated: One perceives the air kasiṇa …🔽One perceives the blue kasiṇa …

analyzed: pīta kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti  lohita kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti
translated: One perceives the yellow kasiṇa …🔽One perceives the red kasiṇa …
One perceives the white kasiṇa …
One perceives the space kasiṇa …

original: viññāṇakasiṇameko sañjānāti uddhaṁ adho tiriyaṁ advayaṁ appamāṇaṁ.
analyzed: viññāṇa kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti uddham adhas tiriyam advayam appamāṇa
translated: One perceives the consciousness kasiṇa above, below, across—unbroken, unbounded, and measureless.
These ten dhammas should be developed.
Which ten dhammas should be comprehended?
Ten sense spheres:

original: cakkhāyatanaṁ, rūpāyatanaṁ, sotāyatanaṁ, saddāyatanaṁ, ghānāyatanaṁ, gandhāyatanaṁ, jivhāyatanaṁ, rasāyatanaṁ, kāyāyatanaṁ, phoṭṭhabbāyatanaṁ.
analyzed: cakkhāyatana rūpāyatana sotāyatana saddāyatana ghānāyatana gandhāyatana jivhāyatana rasāyatana kāyāyatana phoṭṭhabbāyatana
translated: The sense sphere of the eye, the sense sphere of forms, the sense sphere of the ear, the sense sphere of sounds, the sense sphere of the nose, the sense sphere of smells, the sense sphere of the tongue, the sense sphere of tastes, the sense sphere of the body, the sense sphere of touches.
These ten dhammas should be comprehended.
Which ten dhammas should be given up?
Ten kinds of wrongness:

original: micchādiṭṭhi, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvācā, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi, micchāñāṇaṁ, micchāvimutti.
analyzed: micchā diṭṭhi micchā saṅkappaḥ micchā vācā micchā kammantaḥ micchā ājīvaḥ micchā vāyāmaḥ micchā sati micchā samādhi micchā ñāṇa micchā vimutti
translated: Wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong concentration, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.
These ten dhammas should be abandoned.
• “Which ten dhammas are on the side of decline?
Ten unskillful courses of action:

original: pāṇātipāto, adinnādānaṁ, kāmesumicchācāro, musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo, abhijjhā, byāpādo, micchādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: pāṇa atipātaḥ adinnādāna kāmesu micchācāraḥ musāvādaḥ pisuṇā vācā pharusā vācā samphappalāpaḥ abhijjhā byāpādaḥ micchādiṭṭhi
translated: Taking life, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, telling lies, divisive speech, harsh speech, idle chatter, greed, ill will, and wrong view.
These ten dhammas are on the side of decline.
• “Which ten dhammas are on the side of distinction?
Ten skillful courses of action:

Ten perceptions:

translated: the perception of unattractiveness, the perception of death, the perception of the repulsiveness of food, the perception of non-delight in the entire world, the perception of impermanence, the perception of suffering in the impermanent, the perception of not-self in what is suffering, the perception of abandoning, the perception of dispassion, the perception of cessation.

• “Which ten dhammas should be directly known?
Ten grounds for decline:
For one with right view, wrong view is declined.

original: Ye ca micchādiṭṭhipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.🔽Sammāsaṅkappassa micchāsaṅkappo …pe…🔽sammāvācassa micchāvācā …
analyzed: ye ca micchādiṭṭhi paccayā aneke pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ sambhavanti te ca ssa nijjiṇṇāḥ honti  sammāsaṅkappassa micchāsaṅkappaḥ pe  sammāvācassa micchāvācā
translated: And the many evil, unskillful qualities that come into play with wrong view as their condition are also declined.🔽For one with right resolve, wrong resolve is declined. …🔽For one with right speech, wrong speech is declined. …
For one with right action, wrong action is declined. …
For one with right livelihood, wrong livelihood is declined. …🔽For one with right effort, wrong effort is declined. …
For one with right mindfulness, wrong mindfulness is declined. …
Wrong concentration is worn away by right concentration. …
Wrong knowledge is worn away by right knowledge.
Wrong freedom is worn away by right freedom.

original: Ye ca micchāvimuttipaccayā aneke pāpakā akusalā dhammā sambhavanti, te cassa nijjiṇṇā honti.
analyzed: ye ca micchāvimutti paccayā aneke pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ sambhavanti te ca ssa nijjiṇṇāḥ honti
translated: And the many bad, unwholesome qualities that arise because of wrong freedom are also worn away.
These ten dhammas should be directly known.
